name: 2-methylbenzyl chloride
Reason: The compound 2-methylbenzyl chloride has a benzene ring as its basic structure, which has a melting point of 5.5 degrees Celsius. Adding a chlorine atom (-Cl) generally decreases the melting point due to the introduction of a polar group that disrupts the regularity of the molecular crystal structure; this effect might be around -20 degrees Celsius. On the other hand, adding a methyl group (+CH3) typically increases the melting point slightly because of the increased molecular weight and van der Waals forces; this effect could be about +5 degrees Celsius. Furthermore, the addition of a -CH2 group (methylene bridge between the benzene and chlorine) also increases the melting point due to increased molecular weight and van der Waals interactions; this could add another +5 to the melting point. Combining these effects for an approximate value gives us an expected shift.
Test (Predicted reason):
The base structure of benzene has a melting point of 5.5°C. The addition of a methyl group to the benzene ring typically increases the melting point due to an increase in molecular weight and van der Waals forces, estimated at around 5°C. The chlorine atom attached to the methyl group is expected to further increase the melting point due to its electronegativity and the dipole-dipole interactions it can engage in, estimated at around 10°C.
